content: Several of the largest sector and industry ETFs have been mauled by the bear recently.Alerian MLP (AMLP) sits 45% below its 52-week high, putting it firmly in bear market territory. It invests in energy-focused master limited partnerships, typically midstream, pipeline companies.IShares Nasdaq Biotechnology (IBB) is trading 34% off its old high.Then there's Utilities Select Sector SPDR (XLU), a defensively oriented exchange traded fund.Think of it as your bear pepper spray for tough markets. It's worth considering an overweight to utility companies, especially since the broad-market ETF such as SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) that you may already own only has a 3% stake in the sector.XLU has gained 5.7% year to date through Feb. 17 vs. a 5.4% loss for SPY.So far in 2016, AMLP stumbled 18% and IBB tumbled 21%.Meanwhile, XLU hit a new 52-week high of 47 last week as the broad market was sinking. It has a Relative Strength Rating of 85, which means it is outgunning 85% of the stocks and ETFs in the IBD database.That momentum helped it earn a place on the elite IBD Leaderboard, becoming the first ETF to do so.Leaderboard holds stocks with stellar technical and fundamental factors, which offer investors the most potential for the biggest gains. Only three other stocks made that list Thursday -- AT&T (T), Ross Stores (ROST) and Reynolds American (RAI).XLU led these peers with a 2% gain on the stock market today. Along the way, it reclaimed a 46.24 buy point and formed a new handle area with a 47.10 entry. Shares are in a buy range.The $7.62 billion ETF last broke out of a base, on Oct. 24, 2014. Investors who jumped on that opportunity pocketed a 12% gain if they sold when XLU peaked at 49.78 three months later.Keep in mind that while breakouts from sound bases often lead to substantial gains, breakouts can fail. So among wise investors' sell rules are those that will help them cut any losses short.XLU offers broad exposure to 29 high-yielding utility companies in the S&P 500. As such, it has a large- and midcap skew.Top holdings include NextEra Energy (NEE), Duke Energy (DUK) and Southern Co. (SO)The utilities sector is one of the steadiest segments of the market."This fund has been less volatile than the broader market because of the sector's generally stable cash flows and lower sensitivity to economic cycles," Robert Goldsborough, a Morningstar analyst, wrote in a recent report.However, the sector could get hurt if the Fed stays on track with its proposed four interest-rate hikes this year."Higher rates generally make fixed-income instruments more attractive on a relative basis and make bond-like equities, such as utilities companies, less attractive," Goldsborough said.XLU has a 0.14% expense ratio and a 3.5% yield.It's the top-performing utility ETF year to date.

James "Buck" Duke made his first fortune in tobacco, changing the way Americans used it. He made his second fortune in electrical generation, bringing light and power to many parts of the Carolinas for the first time.His entrepreneurial brilliance was matched only by the generosity of his philanthropy later in life.Duke (1856-1925) came from a line of subsistence farmers in rural North Carolina, near Durham.His father, Washington, who went by Wash, started a tobacco processing business that bought, cured and sold the leaf to retailers.Wash's insight, which would help make his son one of the nation's wealthiest men, was that the money was not in growing tobacco, but in buying, aging, curing and preparing it for retail.After a six-month course of studies at Eastman Business College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., 18-year-old Buck quickly became the brains and heart of his father's business.The young man excelled in devising ways to cut expenses and increase profit — even traveling at night in order to avoid hotel bills.He also had an eye for talent.He hired Edward Small, a salesman who set a lasting trend when he acquired permission to use the image and endorsement of Madame Rhea, a famous French actress touring in Atlanta in 1879.New LookThe resulting ad, depicting a beautiful woman (at that time shockingly) promoting cigarettes, caused a sensation when it appeared in the Atlanta Constitution and on billboards all over town.Local sales skyrocketed.Duke was a visionary in his belief that cigarettes — still an exotic product with a relatively small market in 1870s America — would be the next big thing in tobacco.That butted up against what biographer John Winkler, in "Tobacco Tycoon," called "the popular attitude ... that only sissies and dudes would smoke cigarettes."On a personal level, Duke detested what were termed paper cigarettes, preferring to chew tobacco."He thought that cigarettes were kind of trashy ... the fast food of tobacco," said Stanford professor Robert Proctor, who has written on the history of cigarette smoking.Americans largely agreed, and smoked only 238 million cigarettes in 1879. But by 1910, thanks in no small part to Duke's efforts, they would smoke 8.6 billion of them.Duke's big break — and the cigarette's — came through Virginian inventor James Bonsack, who in 1881 patented a machine that could roll 200 cigarettes per minute.Duke got the inside track on this innovation (and a discount on royalties for using it) by helping Bonsack work out its kinks.By 1884, the machine had been perfected, and Duke put two of them to work for W. Duke, Sons & Co. of Durham 10 hours a day.Together, they produced a quarter-million cigarettes daily for just 30 cents per thousand — 50 times the volume of a skilled roller by hand and at less than half the old manufacturing cost.This abundance of product permitted Buck to start selling into New York, where he set up a second factory with four more of Bonsack's machines.Duke found a residence in Manhattan and began calling on local tobacconists. They dropped their resistance to his products after the Duke brand's celebrity-studded advertising campaign had customers requesting them by name.It helped that the firm gave away paraphernalia — clocks, folding chairs — with company brand logos to dealers who made sufficiently large orders.By 1887, the Duke brands, including Cameo and Crosscut, were gobbling up the market share of the Big Four cigarette outfits of the day. They responded by copying him — automating production and adopting Duke's modern marketing techniques. None could keep up, especially because Duke was so willing to accept a much lower short-term profit to gain that market share.They finally surrendered, agreeing in January 1890 to pool their assets and form the American Tobacco Co., a trust with $25 million (worth $670 million today) market capitalization and with Duke as president.Over 20 years, Duke would oversee the company's 1,200% growth.One reason for the boom was Duke's negotiating a contract with Bonsack for today's equivalent of $34 million in royalties in exchange for exclusive use of his cigarette rolling machine. No other company could use it from 1891 to 1895, giving American a critical competitive advantage in a rocketing market just as cigarette smoking was catching on in earnest.Having conquered cigarettes, Duke employed similar tactics in conquering the chew, snuff and British tobacco markets.In Britain, his competitors surrendered after he promised new retailers they could keep all profits from the sale of his products the first four years. American even got into the retail business, controlling 500 stores by the time the firm was broken up.The GripBy the turn of the century, Duke's trust controlled 93% of the U.S. cigarette market, 80% of the snuff market and 62% of the chew market, Winkler records. By 1906, it had acquired at least 250 companies and exercised a near monopoly over the price of the tobacco crop.Some Kentucky tobacco farmers reacted with a violent campaign of sabotage and reprisals known as the Black Patch Tobacco Wars. In their opening salvo, they torched two of American's tobacco warehouses in Princeton, Ky., and they continued such raids on occasion until the company was broken up.James Buchanan Duke was born in rural North Carolina, where tobacco was a cash crop for many small farmers. His mother died before his second birthday.His father, Wash, was drafted into the Confederate army in 1863 and returned nearly penniless to find that his farm equipment and animals had been plundered in the chaos of the Civil War.The one thing untouched by looters was a storage barn filled with harvested tobacco leaves. With this, he began the tobacco processing business that would become W. Duke, Sons & Co.Wash built a small factory for the task on his property, and by 1872 was processing 60 tons a year. That was only the beginning of Buck's big plans.In 1911, when the Supreme Court ruled that American Tobacco was a monopoly and ordered it broken up, Duke responded like a practical businessman. He drafted the plan by which American would become four companies, each with the assets it needed to compete with all the others in all tobacco markets.Energetic ShiftDuke would thereafter merely remain a large shareholder and give up his management role.He turned his attention to investments he had made the previous decade in hydroelectric power.His dams would modernize the Carolinas and double his wealth.Having incorporated Southern Power Co. (later Duke Power, then Duke Energy (DUK) in 1905, he began scouting and buying land and water rights.Before building dams, he would invest in rural businesses (especially cotton mills) to which he hoped to sell electricity, then make a handy profit after they had been electrified and production increased. By 1913, Southern was providing residential service as well.In 1924, the year before he died of pneumonia, Duke created the Duke Endowment, giving it $107 million in all (worth $1.5 billion now). Today it has grown to $3.4 billion, having spent nearly the same amount on its program areas since inception.Gene Cochrane, the endowment's president, says the endowment is unique for its specific focus on funding institutions."Other philanthropists of his day tended to choose social causes to support," he told IBD. "He chose organizations. It's a different way of doing philanthropy, and it's given us a great deal more focus than some other foundations have."The Duke Endowment supports nonprofit hospitals in the Carolinas and institutions for orphan children. It also supports rural churches and retired ministers."My old daddy always said that if he amounted to anything in life it was due to the Methodist circuit riders who frequently visited his home," Duke said, "and whose preaching and counsel brought out the best that was in him."The endowment supports Duke University, named in honor of the late Washington Duke at the time the endowment was created.

ARLINGTON, Va. — Despite oil near $30 a barrel, the Navy is focused on cutting back fuel consumption to give itself a "tactical and strategic edge" and is on track to have more than 300 ships in service by the end of the decade, according to a top official.At the Surface Navy Association's National Symposium on Thursday, Navy Secretary Ray Mabus said the Navy is on track to boost its fleet to over 300 ships by the end of the decade but still doesn't like comparisons between the fleet now vs. World War I, as technology and the need for ships are changing."Yes we have fewer ships than we had in World War I, but we also have fewer telegraphs," Mabus said.Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) is the nation's largest military shipbuilder. Huntington Ingalls shares closed up 1.7% in the stock market today, after jumping over its 50-day line on Wednesday. The Coast Guard plans to acquire two new icebreakers from the defense contractor.Mabus also touted the use of solar and hybrid power in the armed forces and said that, since 2009, the Navy has reduced oil consumption by 15%, and the Marine Corps has cut oil consumption by 60%."We have become way more efficient in the way we use it," he said. "We don't have to refuel as much, which gives us a tactical and strategic edge."Last week, Duke Energy (DUK) said it would build a 24-megawatt solar project for the Navy in Indiana. SunPower (SPWR) has already built a solar power system for the Navy in California.Duke shares rose 0.9%. SunPower shares closed up 0.4%.Meanwhile at sea, ships are using blends of marine diesel and bio-fuels to cut back on crude oil consumption. The Navy started a program for using drop-in biofuels in aircraft and ships in 2012, including hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids (HEFA), and Fischer-Tropsch (FT) liquids, and it has awarded contracts with Emerald Biofuels, Fulcrum BioEnergy and Red Rock Biofuels to build biorefineries to produce greener fuel.Some commercial airlines are also proponents of alternative fuel sources. Last year, United Continental (UAL) invested in U.S.-based alternative fuels developer Fulcrum.Mabus said the Navy has contracts overseas with companies who get their source of oil from places that aren't in America's best interest. Instead, Mabus is focused on getting contracts for biofuels with companies in friendly countries and in the U.S.Iran, a major oil producer that will come back onto the world market as sanctions are expected to lift soon, seized two American patrol boats in the Persian Gulf earlier this week. The sailors were released, and Mabus said Thursday that the crew appeared to be in "pretty good shape" and that more will be known after the sailors are debriefed.Despite somewhat warmer relations between the U.S. and Iran, Tehran is still at odds with U.S. allies, including Saudi Arabia, the de facto head of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.Biofuels and alternative energy are still expensive, especially with oil near $30 a barrel. Still, later this month the Navy will launch the Great Green Fleet in San Diego to highlight the importance of alternative energy and reducing the reliance on fossil fuels.

Companies are increasingly putting their cash toward dividends and buybacks, trends that benefit shareholders. From 2005 to 2014, S&P; 500 companies increased the sums spent on buybacks and dividends by $428 billion, or 85%, to $934 billion, according to a new report by S&P; Capital IQ.
Moreover, "the amount allocated to repurchases and dividends has risen in each of the past five years, and we see this trend continuing," analysts wrote.
The amounts devoted to dividends and buybacks varies greatly from sector to sector and from company to company.
For the financial sector — a market leader today — the outlook is good. S&P; analysts expect dividends to rise 12% this year, well above most of the other nine S&P; sectors.
Pharmaceuticals have been the largest and most consistent payer of dividends, the study said. The industry single-handedly accounted for 80% of total dividends in 2005-14.

Two companies in IBD's Dividend Leaders screen, Pfizer (PFE) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), are the most generous. Pfizer has been the biggest payer of dividends, about $70 billion in 2012-14; Johnson & Johnson followed with $60.7 billion.
Among industrials, S&P; Capital IQ doesn't expect much change in dividends, although buybacks have been expanding.
General Electric (GE) spent nearly $24 billion on dividends in 2012-14, dwarfing the other major industrial companies.
Telecom giants AT&T; (T) and Verizon (VZ) command yields near 5%. But S&P; Capital IQ analysts think the telecoms will focus more on reducing debt.

S&P; 500 utilities — which tend to pay more than half of their profits in dividends — should continue to raise payouts the next several years at an average annual rate of 4.5% to 6%. Duke Energy (DUK), Southern Co. (SO) and Dominion Resources (D), which all make IBD's Utility Leaders screen, top the sector's dividends.Companies are increasingly putting their cash toward dividends and buybacks, trends that benefit shareholders. Exchange operator Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) agreed Monday to buy Interactive Data Corp. from private-equity firms Silver Lake and Warburg Pincus in a $5.2 billion cash-and-stock deal. The move gives Intercontinental Exchange more presence in financial data and analytics. The deal is expected to close by the end of this year. Shares of Intercontinental Exchange finished down 0.6% in the stock…
Facebook (FB) got a higher price target Friday, while Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Qorvo's (QRVO) price target was lowered and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was downgraded.

Argus hiked its price target on Facebook to 130 from 115 and maintained its buy rating on the stock. After Wednesday's close, the social network reported Q3 earnings and revenue that beat consensus views. Also, the number of active daily Facebook users topped 1 billion for the first time.
Despite the price target hike, Facebook shares closed down 1.5% on thestock market today after gapping up 4.6% Thursday.
Qorvo, which supplies chips to the Apple iPhone, among other devices, had its price target lowered to 70 from 75 by Brean Capital, which still maintained its buy rating on the stock.
Even so, Qorvo shares shot up 23% following Thursday's better-than-expected quarterly earnings report. Apple's stock price rose 0.1%.

Another chipmaker, Nvidia (NVDA), popped 13.9% as several analysts made calls on the stock. Late Thursday, Nvidia beat fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue estimates and guided Q4 earnings higher. MKM Partners upgraded the stock to buy, while Roth Capital, Morgan Stanley and Wedbush all raised their price targets on Nvidia.
Nvidia also supplies graphics chips for Tesla's (TSLA) touchscreen dashboard. Earlier this week, Tesla reported strong quarterly results. Tesla shares closed up 0.25%.

Chipotle was downgraded to neutral from outperform at Robert W. Baird, which lowered its price target on the stock to 675 from 850. The former high flyer has been in a funk of late, with shares dropping nearly 20% since Oct. 13 and losing 0.8% Friday.

Duke Energy (DUK) fell 5.2% after it was downgraded to market perform by BMO Capital a day after the utility giant fell short of quarterly EPS views. Last week, Duke announced plans to buy fellow Charlotte, N.C.-based utility Piedmont Natural Gas (PNY) for $4.9 billion.
First Solar (FSLR) climbed 2.3% after it was initiated at outperform by Macquarie.
Retailer TJX Companies (TJX) fell 1.9% after it was initiated at outperform by RBC Capital.
TripAdvisor (TRIP) sank 6.85% on a downgrade to neutral by Guggenheim Securities and to perform by Canaccord Genuity. On Thursday, TripAdvisor fell short of quarterly EPS views.

Shares of Ralph Lauren (RL) climbed 5.2% after its price target was hiked to 150 from 142 by Telsey Advisory Group, a day after the apparel company's stock price popped nearly 15%. That gain came after Ralph Lauren topped Q3 earnings views and offered a bullish outlook.

Stock futures were mildly lower and trimming losses ahead of Monday's start of trade. Dow futures dipped 19.7 points, well off their hour-earlier lows. Nasdaq 100 futures traded a modest 6.9 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures improved to a 3.9-point decline.

The stock market today starts the week in good standing, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 sitting atop four straight weekly gains and back above their 200-day moving averages for the first time since August. A quick buildup in distribution days — a measure of selling by large-scale investors — left the Nasdaq showing four days and the S&P 500 carrying three. The levels aren't problematic, as long as the quick buildup in distribution stops to give the young uptrend a break.

A busy week of economic news opens rather quietly, with September new-home sales figures due out from the Commerce Department at 10.m. ET. The Dallas Federal Reserve plans to report its regional manufacturing survey for October at 10:30. The focal point of the week is likely to be Wednesday afternoon's policy decision following the two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in Washington.

In earnings news, the week's highlight for many investors will be Apple's (AAPL) report after Tuesday's close. Reynolds American (RAI) and Ford (F) report during the regular session Tuesday. Big oil reports begin to roll out with ConocoPhillips (COP) on Thursday, followed by Dow stocks Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) on Friday.

Before Monday's open, most earnings stirred mild responses. Xerox (XRX) and Check Point Software (CHKP) inched up 1% each after quarterly reports. China-based gaming provider Sohu (SOHU) slipped a fraction.

LendingTree (TREE) was an exception, bolting 15% higher after beating Q3 consensus views by broad margins on both its earnings and revenue lines. Earnings soared 93%; revenue winged up 69%. The online lender closed Friday 24% below a buy point in a steep, third-stage, double-bottom base.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) dropped nearly 5% and remained a center of attention as it launched an 8 a.m. conference call in which Chief Executive Michael Pearson counters "incorrect interpretation of facts" that led the stock to collapse 35% last week.

Piedmont Natural Gas (PNY) jetted 37% on reports that Duke Energy (DUK) agreed to buy the Charlotte, N.C.-based gas distributor in a deal valued at $4.9 billion. It's the most recent of a string of energy producers buying gas distributors. The deal also requires Duke to assume $1.8 billion in Piedmont debt, lifting the overall deal to $6.7 billion. The companies hope to close the transaction by late next year. Duke shares were unchanged in premarket trade.

China-based Ctrip.com International (CTRP) spiked 19%. Search engine operator Baidu (BIDU) leapt 9% after announcing a share exchange that will give Ctrip a 45% voting interest in Qunar Cayman Islands (QUNR). Ctrip is an online broker of hotel reservations, airline tickets and other travel accommodations. Qunar is an online aggregator of travel deals. The exchange leaves Baidu with a 25% voting interest in Ctrip. Qunar shares vaulted 32% higher.

Refiner Northern Tier Energy (NTI) popped 6%. The Tempe, Ariz., company announced Western Refining (WNR) had offered to purchase the remaining portion of the company for 17.50 and 0.2266 of a Western Refining share for each Northern Tier unit. Western currently owns 38% of the company. Western shares remained flat.

Leading stocks were mixed ahead of the open. Signet Jewelers (SIG) led the IBD 50 list, rising a bit more than 1% before the open. Shares ended Friday just below a fresh high and 1% above a 143.03 buy point after clearing a flat base in weak trade.
Juniper Networks (JNPR) took the largest premarket loss on the list, down 2%. The networking gear and service provider posted a 6% gain in heavy trade last week, ending 8% above a 29.23 buy point.

Overseas, China's markets closed little changed, with the Shanghai Composite up 0.5% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng 0.2% lower. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 rose 0.7%. Europe's leading indexes were tightly mixed heading into midday action.

The dollar slipped. Bonds rose. Oil added pennies per barrel, but West Texas Intermediate held below $45, Brent at $48. Natural gas fell 4%. Gold was effectively flat, just above $1,167 an ounce.Stock futures were mildly lower and trimming losses ahead of Monday's start of trade. Electricity provider Southern Co. said Monday it will buy natural gas distributor AGL Resources, creating the second-largest utility company in the U.S. based on the number of customers, behind only Exelon. Southern (SO) will pay $66 cash per AGL (GAS) share. The enterprise value of the deal is approximately $12 billion, according to the companies, including debt of $8 billion.…

It's been a tough year so far for utility stocks. No surprise there, since interest rates are widely expected to start heading higher soon, and that's generally not good news for utilities that are known for their heavy debt loads. On the other hand, utilities are often a safe haven for investors during periods of market tumult. And with nine…

Utility stocks have maintained a leadership position in the market as investors have shunned growth stocks in favor of more defensive names. It's not exactly a new story, but it shows no signs of ending.Selling pressure has been muted in natural gas distributor AGL Resources (GAS) as the stock holds near highs. The price of natural gas has been in freefall for a few months now, but investors are gravitating toward yield, and AGL has it.Not only is the U.S. awash in oil, it's also producing a lot of natural gas. In January, the U.S. Energy Information Administration said that gas output from the Marcellus Shale formation could advance to 16.55 billion cubic feet a day in February, up 21% from a year ago.Earlier this week, the company raised its quarterly dividend by 4% to 51 cents a share. The dividend is payable on March 1 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 13. On an annualized basis, the new dividend is $2.04 a share, giving it a yield of around 3.6%.In December 2010, AGL announced plans to acquire Nicor for $2.4 billion. The deal closed about one year later, giving AGL a big presence in northern Illinois and making it one of the largest gas-only distributors in the U.S., with about 4.5 million customers.In November, AGL reported third-quarter profit of 22 cents a share, up 5% from a year ago but well below views. Sales rose 3% to $589 million.Q4 earnings, due later this month, are seen rising 24% to 84 cents a share.In September, Dominion Resources (D) entered into a joint venture with three other firms — Duke Energy (DUK), Piedmont Natural Gas (PNY) and AGL — to build a $4.5 billion-$5 billion natural gas pipeline serving North Carolina and Virginia.Another thing that AGL has going for it is rising mutual fund sponsorship. Fund ownership has increased for eight straight quarters, from 512 funds to 669.
Duke Energy (DUK), the largest U.S. electric power company, recently hiked its quarterly dividend for the 10th straight year.

The latest increase, announced Aug. 13, boosted the quarterly payout by 1.5 cents, or 2% to 79.5 cents a share. The annual dividend of $3.18 a share yields 4.4% at the current share price. That's much higher than the S&P 500 average of 1.88%
The stock has risen about 6% this year, around a percentage point below the S&P 500's gain. It's currently working on a flat base with a 75.23 buy point.
The Charlotte, N.C.-based company supplies energy to 7.2 million customers in the Carolinas, the Midwest and Florida. It also provides natural gas distribution services in Ohio and Kentucky.
Duke announced plans Monday to invest $500 million in solar power to meet North Carolina's requirement that more of its electricity come from renewable energy.

Meanwhile, the company recently joined a consortium of three other utility companies to build a 550-mile natural-gas pipeline from West Virginia to the southeast corner of North Carolina. The pipeline is expected to begin operating by the end of 2018.

Zacks Equity Research said the deal would help Duke reduce its reliance on coal and tap into a boom in natural gas production in the region, thanks to new technologies such as hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling.
Duke has risen steadily since hitting a bottom of 35.16 amid the 2008-09 recession.
As with most utilities, Duke's profit has been steady. The three-year profit growth rate is 1%, while the three-year sales growth rate is a robust 27%.

The company has been benefiting this summer from higher temperatures, which have forced customers to use more air conditioning. Special Report: Income Investing
Utility stocks have produced strong returns in recent years, thanks to rising share prices and steady dividend growth.

But the prospect of higher interest rates could erode some of the advantages that utility stocks have enjoyed. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield shot up to as high as 2.63% in mid-September from a low of 2.33% in late August amid expectations that the Federal Reserve will start raising borrowing costs in the middle of next year. The yield currently stands at around 2.44%.
Higher yields would make utilities' dividend yields — currently about 4% — less attractive in comparison to Treasuries.
"For the last five years, all you had to do was buy a basket" of utility stocks, said Mario Gabelli, CEO of GAMCO Investors. "For the next five years, you want to be more selective."

The utilities sector stood at No. 12 out of the 33 sectors tracked by IBD as of Friday. Of the four utility subgroups, only the electric power group ranks in the top half of IBD's 197 industry groups. The other groups are diversified, gas distribution and water supply.
Gabelli said he prefers companies with assets in the natural gas business and those engaged in financial engineering — such as those buying companies and splitting them up.
National Fuel Gas (NFG), NextEra Energy (NEE) and Energy Transfer Equity LP (ETE) are the top holdings in the Gabelli Utilities Fund , which has $3.5 billion in assets.

Of those, Energy Transfer Equity, which operates oil and natural gas pipelines and storage facilities, has the highest IBD Composite Rating. The stock has risen 45% this year, easily outpacing the S&P 500's 5% gain.
Energy Transfer's long-term dividend growth rate is 8%. And its annual dividend of $1.52 a share yields 2.6% at the current share price, also well above the S&P 500 average.
Many analysts consider utilities stocks to be overvalued because they've already enjoyed strong advances. They say higher interest rates would dent their appeal.
Yet Ed Perks, who manages $97 billion Franklin Income Fund , said utility stocks remain a "great match" with an income strategy.
"There's a pretty wide range of companies today in the utility sector that are pretty yield-oriented and are attractive because of how stable that yield is," he said.
He said utilities that have the highest earnings potential will be in the best position to withstand higher interest rates and raise dividends over time.

He noted that NextEra Energy (NEE) rose 24% and Sempra Energy (SE) climbed 30% in 2013 despite strong gains in the 10-year Treasury yield sparked by expectations that the Fed would boost interest rates sooner than expected. By contrast, utility stocks that had lower growth profiles were impacted a little more, he said.
Perks said he expects "modestly higher" yields of about 3% to 3.25% on the 10-year Treasury. "Companies that are growing dividends will still be an attractive place to invest in," he added.
The top holdings in Franklin Utilities Fund include Edison International (EIX), NextEra, Duke Energy (DUK) and Sempra Energy.

John Kohli, who manages the $5.8 billion fund, said Duke Energy is in "good growth territories" such as the sunbelt states of Florida and the Carolinas, where there's "fairly good customer growth." "It's a company that looks in our mind to have a bright future," he said.
Duke has a three-year earnings growth rate of 1% but a 27% revenue growth rate over that time.
Profit this year is seen rising 6%, followed by a 4% increase in 2015.
The company has increased its dividend for 10 straight years. The annual payout of $3.18 a share yields 4.2% at the current share price.
Sempra Energy is investing in Liquefied Natural Gas infrastructure and is also pursuing wind power and solar power projects in the Southwest, Kohli said.
"The industry has been very proactive in getting ahead of the regulatory process," Kohli said, adding that there's "a lot of growth coming out of meeting compliance."

Utility stocks got a vote of confidence Sept. 10, when Charles Munger, vice chairman of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate, said Berkshire will greatly expand investment in utilities companies with the aim of becoming the biggest utilities business in the U.S. Munger said he expects to earn 8% to 9% on the investments.

"The chance that we won't have a good return in that investment is practically zero," the Wall Street Journal quoted him as saying at the annual meeting of the Daily Journal.Special Report: Income InvestingUtility stocks have produced strong returns in recent years, thanks to rising share prices and steady dividend growth.But the prospect of higher interest rates could erode some of the advantages that utility stocks have enjoyed. Independent power producer Dynegy's (DYN) $6.25 billion purchase agreement for Midwest power plant assets got a thumbs up from investors, who drove its shares up sharply Friday.
Dynegy will acquire 12,500 megawatts of coal and natural gas generation capacity from Duke Energy (DUK) and Energy Capital Partners, nearly doubling its existing energy portfolio to 26,000 MW.
Dynegy shares were up about 9% on the stock market today. Duke fell less than 1%.
The deal came after Duke, the largest electric power holding company in the U.S., said in mid-February that it intended to exit its Midwest commercial generation business.
Dynegy, which serves parts of Illinois, Pennsylvania, California, Nevada, New York and Massachusetts, will pay $2.8 billion for Duke's assets and $3.45 billion for ECP's assets.
The transactions are expected to close in early 2015.
Houston-based Dynegy, which finished its exit from bankruptcy in November 2013 as a smaller, leaner company, expects cost reductions of $40 million a year.

"The addition of these portfolios is forecasted to significantly improve our financial outlook by tripling our 2015 adjusted EBITDA and being massively accretive to adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow per share in 2015 and beyond," CEO Robert Flexon said in a statement.

Stocks opened mostly lower but quickly turned and crept into positive territory early Friday.

The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq edged up 0.1% each. The S&P 500 posted a fractional gain. Small caps lagged, with the Russell 2000 still down 0.4%. Volume was tracking lower across the board.

The stock market today appeared to turn higher in response to opening comments from Fed chief Janet Yellen, who was speaking to a group of global finance and economic leaders in Jackson Hole, Wyo. Yellen said the Fed was carefully weighing labor market slack relative to the need for and timing of any potential increase in the Fed's target interest rate. She also said recent unemployment data appeared to overstate the economy's progress.

In stocks, Dynegy (DYN) spiked 12% after announcing it would pay $6.25 billion for a portfolio of generation assets from Duke Energy (DUK) and Energy Capital Partners. The deal would nearly double the generation capacity of the electrical utility, which emerged from bankruptcy protection in 2012. The jump left Dynegy shares below the left-side high in a 31% deep consolidation begun in June. Duke Energy shares rose a fraction.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) bolted 8% higher after the progenitor of K-cup coffee announced a multi-year deal with Kraft Foods (KRFT). The multiyear deal aims to make Kraft brands including Maxwell House, Gevalia and Yuban coffee available in "portion packs" compatible with Keurig consumer and commercial brewing systems. The gain lifted shares to just below a 128.60 buy point in an eight week flat base. Kraft shares rose a fraction.

Ross Stores (ROST) snapped up 7% in heavy trade. The discount retailer late Thursday reported Q2 earnings that were comfortably above analyst forecasts. Revenue met expectations. Q3 earnings guidance also met consensus views, while management gave Q4 guidance below consensus. Gross margins increased sharply, and the company reported a 45-basis-point decrease in selling, general and administrative expenses. The move hoisted shares back above 10-week support as the stock attempts to climb the right side of a nine-month consolidation.

On the IBD 50 list, GasLog (GLOG) dragged down 2%, putting it down 7% so far for the week. The stock triggered the 8% sell rule after a June breakout attempt failed, and after diving below support at its 10-week moving average in heavy trade July 31.

Ambarella (AMBA) slipped 2% but remains up 4% so far in a third straight weekly gain. Dividend-paying funds have outperformed the broad stock market over the past 15 years. Only four of the highest-yielding dividend payers are also beating the S&P 500 year-to-date and only two have also outperformed the benchmark in the past five years. Pimco Fundamental IndexPlus , with a 12-month yield of 13.45%, is up 7% year-to-date vs. 6% for the S&P 500.…

After re-emerging from bankruptcy in October 2012 as a smaller and leaner company, Dynegy is powering up again.The Houston-based independent power producer increased its capacity by around 50% in early December. That's when it acquired 4,000 additional megawatts of power through five coal-fired power plants in Illinois, bringing its total to more than 13,000 megawatts of power in six states.And it's looking to buy more. Still, what it owns today is a fraction of what it owned in its heyday, before Enron imploded in 2001 and caused credit to dry up and the industry to spiral downwards.Dynegy (DYN) logged nearly $1.5 billion in revenue in 2013, down from $42 billion in 2001.The company had previously owned power plants in about a dozen states and several foreign countries. It also ran gas-processing plants, pipelines, a utility and an energy-trading business.Dynegy stumbled from "ill-timed strategic decisions and cratering power prices," Morningstar analyst Andrew Bischof said in a note.A Power ShiftIn 2011, the board hired Robert Flexon to lead restructuring efforts and then named him CEO. He previously worked as chief finance officer at utility operator UGI and NRG Energy (NRG), a much larger rival.Dynegy now provides wholesale power and capacity to utilities, cooperatives, municipalities and large industrial customers.The company owns nine coal plants in Illinois, including the five acquired in December from power company Ameren Corp. (AEE), which wanted out of the deregulated state of Illinois to focus more on its regulated businesses. But it was the kind of business Dynegy liked."We felt we were in a position to operate them more effectively and efficiently since we have similar facilities also located in Illinois," said Katy Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Dynegy.Those acquired coal plants are broken out in financial reports as Illinois Power Holdings, or IPH.In California, Dynegy still has a natural-gas fired plant in Monterey County, Calif., and a small fuel-oil plant in Oakland. It recently retired an older natural gas-fired plant in Morro Bay, but is exploring renewable energy opportunities at the site. In the Northeast, it has three small natural gas fired plants — in upstate New York, Bangor, Me., and Reading, Pa."Management has done a great job in fleet (plant) performance," Bischof said in a phone interview.In the first quarter, a key financial metric in Dynegy's industry, adjusted EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) jumped to $152 million from $43 million a year earlier. The gain was driven by improved spark spreads (a metric for estimating profitability) in the natural gas segment, higher energy prices for coal and the new IPH segment, with its five coal plants.Management kept adjusted EBITDA guidance for 2014 at $300-$350 million, even though executives have said they expect to exceed that forecast.Resources For RevenueThe company is currently in a "sweet spot," Bischof said. Natural gas prices have risen to around $4, making cheaper coal "more competitive." Meanwhile, tougher environmental regulations have caused coal-plant closures. As coal capacity tightens, power prices rise.Dynegy gets paid for the electricity its plants generate and also for their capacity, or their ability to produce power when needed.Power companies are paid via regional transmission organizations that manage supply and demand. In Illinois, the company's dominant market, Dynegy is mostly paid by a system operator known as MISO.A year ago, the auction clearing price for capacity in the 2013-14 planning year was 3 cents per kilowatt per month, but this year in the annual MISO auction in mid-April the price spiked to 50 cents for the 2014-15 planning year. Planning years for MISO run June to May.The price jump "serves as a signal that markets are tightening," Sullivan said. "So we can enter into agreements with utilities or large industrial customers for higher prices."Readying For Price HikesEven before the recent auction, in anticipation of higher prices, Dynegy had been entering into bilateral transactions as high as $2 to $2.50 per kilowatt per month for planning years from 2015 to 2019, she says.The transmission organization PJM Interconnection completed an auction last week that also resulted in sharply higher prices, increasing revenue potential for power companies in its covered region. Dynegy has a small portion of its assets under PJM's domain (one plant in northern Illinois and one near Reading, Pa.) but is interested in exporting some energy and capacity from MISO to PJM.Its IPH segment recently secured 240 megawatts of transmission into PJM, effective for the 2017/2018 planning year.Meanwhile, Dynegy is actively looking to gain more power via additional acquisitions. Since its hands are full managing plants in Illinois, they'll likely be in or near other areas where Dynegy operates."There is a handful available or expected to be available over the next several months and we will evaluate those opportunities as they come to market," Sullivan said.In a note on May 8, UBS analyst Julien Dumoulin-Smith said there's a "50% deal probability" with Duke Energy (DUK) and various co-owned Duke assets.Deal With Duke?Duke, the largest electric power holding company in the U.S., said in mid-February that it intended to exit its volatile Midwest commercial generation business, which includes ownership interest in 13 power plants. Eleven are in Ohio, one is in Illinois and one is in Pennsylvania.Dumoulin-Smith also sees potential candidates among many diversified utilities as they seek to reduce their exposure to commodity swings, as Ameren did with its Illinois coal plants.The five coal plants now in Dynegy's hands have necessary environmental controls, Sullivan says. But Dynegy is spending $250 million to finish a scrubber project at one to curb release of the pollutant sulfur dioxide, a regulated emission.The prior owner had already spent $250 million on the project, which is expected to be completed in 2019."Regulations change and become stricter. To meet future compliance we have to make that investment," Sullivan said.Top executives were unavailable for comment. CEO Flexon said in a May 8 conference call that Dynegy is actively looking to make more acquisitions, but said he didn't expect a deal to close this year. The UBS analyst expects a deal to close in the first quarter of 2015, whether with Duke or another party.
Stock futures were steady, pointing to a mixed open Wednesday.

Dow futures traded 22.4 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were down a fraction. Nasdaq 100 futures held 2.6 points into positive territory as Apple (AAPL), Priceline.com (PCLN) and Google (GOOG) all leaned higher in premarket trade.

The stock market today faces a quiet economic calendar, but a busy roster of earnings reports — especially in the after hours session. Among the early reports out, chip sector stocks were in sharp focus.
Chip equipment maker ASML Holding (ASML) climbed 6% in premarket action. The Netherlands-based company reported an 80% jump in Q4 revenue, with both revenue and EPS topping consensus views.
Management lowered Q1 revenue guidance below expectations. The stock has been consolidating and largely below its 10-week moving average since October.

Cree (CREE) climbed more than 3% ahead of the open. The chip and LED lighting products maker reported after Tuesday's close its fiscal Q2 EPS jumped 44% and revenue popped 20%, both well above expectations.
Q3 sales and earnings guidance was in line with expectations. Management noted "strong growth in LED fixtures and LED bulbs" was a key revenue driver.
The stock has been climbing, working to hold support since late November, after lopping through two sharp corrections.

On the downside, IBM (IBM) slipped 3% after reporting late Tuesday its revenue fell more than expected in Q4. IBM shares inched higher over the past five weeks, climbing off the bottom of a nine-month downtrend.
Chip developer Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) was down 7% after trimming a 10% tumble. Q4 earnings met, revenue beat consensus expectations, boosted by gaming console industry sales.
The company warned a Q1 revenue decline could dip below consensus expectations as those sales eased. The stock trades below 5.
Luxury handbag maker Coach (COH) was down 5% after trimming early losses. Both earnings and revenue missed consensus estimates in the New York-based company's fiscal Q2.
North American comparable store sales dropped 13.6% in a third straight quarterly decline. Sales in China rose 25%. The stock has been in a downtrend for 21 months.

Overseas, the Shanghai Composite vaulted 2.2%, rising further from Monday's five-month low after China's central bank moved to ease credit conditions ahead of the country's week-long Lunar New Year holiday in February. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 0.2% each.
Europe's major indexes held slight losses near mid-session.

The dollar edged up vs. the euro and the yen. Oil and natural gas continued higher, with oil pushing above $95 a barrel and natural gas up 2% and ahead 5% so far for the week. Investors in income stocks typically hold for the long term. They're less interested in the daily or weekly ups and downs of a stock than whether it can deliver modest, but dependable, dividend increases year after year.So whether a stock is setting up in a base or not is of less interest that it would be to a growth investor hoping to catch the next rally.But on the theory it's good to get off to a good start with a stock, there are numerous stocks breaking out that are on IBD's dividend leaders list that are setting up in bases.Public Service Enterprise Group (PEG) is in the late stages of forming a cup base. It's New Jersey's largest provider of electric and gas service with 2.2 million electric and 1.8 million gas customers.It also owns a feet of power plants with more than 13,000 megawatts of generating capacity in the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast regions.The company pays a regular quarterly dividend of 39 cents a share, which works out to an annualized yield of 3.7%. Earnings have not grown much in the past few years. The five-year annualized growth rate is a negative 2%.Duke Energy (DUK) serves 7.3 million customers in the Southeast and Midwest. It announced Thursday it's selling its international business, which consists of generating capacity in South and Central America.The stock has made a strong upward move the past two weeks and might be forming the right side of a base. The stock pays an 82.5-cent quarterly dividend, which works out to a 4.2% annualized yield.Another utility, Great Plains Energy (GXP) might be forming the right side of a base. It pays a 26.25-cent dividend, which equates to a 3.6% dividend yield.

General Electric (GE) caught some investors by surprise with its announcement that the "GE of the future" will include renewable energy, in addition to power and aviation.XThe decision was a reversal from November 2017, when reports arose that a post-restructuring GE would focus on power, aviation and health — its three biggest industrial segments in terms of revenue and profit.Morningstar equity analyst Joshua Aguilar considers the decision last month to keep renewable energy instead of health to be "a bit of a pivot," but one that actually makes sense.He noted renewables are poised to compete with fossil fuels subsidy-free from a levelized cost of electricity standpoint, and have a lower environmental impact to boot."When wind is cheaper (unsubsidized) and better for the environment, it's a bit of no-brainer," he said. "Renewables are becoming really attractive."Aviation, power and renewables also share the underlying turbine technology, creating business synergies.Shares rose 1.6% to 14.17 in today's stock market action, retaking their 50-day average.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseBut the company's renewables bet is "not a slum dunk," Aguilar added.Wind energy suffers from the same intense price competition to gain market share that has whacked the power unit. Top rival wind-turbine producers include Denmark's Vestas and Siemens (SIEGY) Gamesa.According to GE, its renewable energy segment is seeing "strong revenue and orders growth from repowering projects, new product introductions and digital capability."In 2017, the unit generated $10.3 billion in revenue and turned a $0.7 billion profit. Orders grew 1% to $10 billion, while backlog increased 15% to $15 billion.Duke Energy (DUK), the largest U.S. electric utility, has expanded into renewables with investments of almost $6 billion in 60 solar installations and 20 wind farms.Many of those projects harness GE's technology.Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:If General Electric Breaks Up, Should You Break Up With GE's Stock?How GE Could Become The Apple Of The Industrial InternetDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisSiemens, Alibaba Team Up On Industrial Internet Of Things For China

Stocks got slammed again Friday, as a major reversal sent key market index funds crashing to cap a very bad week.PowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ) plunged 2.3%, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) sank 2% and SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) gave up 1.6% in the stock market today. SPY fell to its 200-day moving average.On the Dow, Nike and Boeing held slim gains after rising 3% each intraday. They were the only two advancers. Athletic shoe giant Nike reported quarterly results late Thursday that topped views and offered a bullish outlook. But DowDuPont (DWDP), 3M (MMM) and Pfizer (PFE) lost more than 3% apiece.Big-cap techs showed continued weakness: Intel (INTC), Microsoft (MSFT) and Apple (AAPL) each fell 2% or more. Apple extended its slide for a sixth straight session and is now 10% off its high.Banks, semiconductor ad technology led the downside among sector funds. VanEck Vectors Semiconductor (SMH) tumbled 3% to take out its 50-day moving average. Dow component Intel fell 2.7%, while graphics chip designer Nvidia (NVDA) slid nearly 4% and rolled back below its 50-day line for the second time this week. Micron Technology (MU), which reported earnings late Thursday, was down nearly 8%.Investors flocked to a safe haven Thursday as technology and most other sectors got routed amid heightened trade war fears.Most equity ETFs saw losses. But Utilities Select Sector SPDR (XLU) held on for a 0.4% gain and even managed to close above its 50-day moving average. The defensive ETF has been testing that support line the past week. When the market is in confirmed uptrend, a rebound off the 50-day can set up a potential buy opportunity. But when the uptrend is under pressure, all buys are at greater risk than usual.Also note that since late January, the 50-day line has been below the 200-day line. That's a bearish sign. However, the big tech sell-off begs the question: Is sector rotation occurring? Utilities and other defensive sectors tend to outperform when high-growth areas like tech underperform.XLU may also be shaping the bottom of a base as it continues to consolidate near the 50-day. The ETF is currently 13% off its 52-week high.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseThe $6.8 billion fund, which tracks the Utilities Select Sector Index, marked its 19th anniversary in December. Electric utilities accounted for 62% of assets as of March 31, followed by 33% in multi-utilities. Independent power and renewable electricity producers made up nearly 3%, while water utilities represented just over 2%.Top holdings included NextEra Energy (NEE), Duke Energy (DUK) and Southern Co. (SO). NextEra has fared the best this year with a 3.6% gain since Jan. 1. The other two are underwater. But what helps make utilities a defensive play are hefty dividends that can offset at least part of poor price performance. In fact, XLU's annualized yield is 3.57%, well above the S&P 500's average 1.85% payout.The fund carries a 0.13% expense ratio.Thursday's pick, First Trust U.S. Equity Opportunities (FPX), gave up 3.5% as the market sold off.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Stocks Sell Off Hard On Trade War Fears, But This Sector Went UpDow Slips But Chevron Stock Surges, And Apple Tests Key SupportChinese FANGs Are In KraneShares China Internet Fund

Russian hackers are attacking critical U.S. infrastructure, including the energy grid, nuclear power plants, and airports, according to U.S. government officials.XWater processing plants are among the other targets being repeatedly tested by rolling attacks. Last year, more than a dozen power plants in seven states were breached due to Russia's ongoing campaign of cyberattacks.Energy Secretary Rick Perry told the House Appropriations Subcommittee Thursday cyberattacks are "literally happening hundreds of thousands of times a day. ... The warfare that goes on in the cyberspace is real, it's serious, and we must lead the world."Such attacks were cited as being one of the reasons the Trump administration imposed sanctions on a series of Russian organizations and individuals Thursday. In a doomsday scenario, such attacks could leave millions without water and electricity.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseUtility giant Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) was up 2.1% on the stock market today. Duke Energy (DUK) rose 1.1%, Sempra Energy (SRE) 0.7%, Edison International (EIX) 1.8% and Southern Co. (SO) 0.6%.An alert issued by the Department of Homeland Security and the FBI Thursday laid out in more detail what the Russians have been targeting, and how they are going about it."Since at least March 2016, Russian government cyber actors ... targeted government entities and multiple U.S. critical infrastructure sectors, including the energy, nuclear, commercial facilities, water, aviation, and critical manufacturing sectors," the alert said.The techniques being employed include sending spear-phishing emails from compromised legitimate accounts, host-based exploitation and the targeting of industrial control system infrastructure.Russian operatives are also using the hacks for credentials gathering and open-source and network reconnaissance.While the alert did not disclose how successful the attacks were, it said hackers "targeted small commercial facilities' networks where they staged malware, conducted spear phishing, and gained remote access into energy sector networks." They also tried to hide their activities by creating new accounts on the staging targets to perform cleanup operations.While information theft was one of the goals, a key prize would have been gaining control of systems used by infrastructure. They could then launch attacks that could leave millions without water and power.An even more worrying prospect would be hackers gaining control of a nuclear power plant. A sudden shutdown can trigger safety systems designed to disperse excess heat and prevent a meltdown, though safety systems themselves may be vulnerable to attack. However, the operating systems used at such plants are usually decades-old legacy controls that cannot be exploited by hackers.The Department of Homeland Security previously said cyberattacks on critical infrastructure are "one of the most serious national security challenges we must confront."YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:As Trump Sanctions Putin's Russia, Will Dems Revert To Their Fallback Position — Appeasement? Apple (AAPL) joined the tech rally, rising 3% to take out the 160.97 buy point of a cup with handle, amid reports of strong demand for its upcoming iPhone X. Facebook (FB) also surged past a 175.59 flat-base entry and was trading in buy range.But Chevron (CVX) and Merck (MRK) weighed on the Dow Jones industrials with drops of more than 3% apiece.Among sector plays, tech, banks and semiconductors led the upside, while retail, homebuilders and health funds lagged. SPDR S&P Retail (XRT) sank nearly 2% as component stock J.C. Penney (JCP) plunged 16% on a disappointing earnings forecast.Gold and oil funds were mostly higher, along with their respective underlying commodity prices.Utilities have been outperforming while tech stocks pull back as sector rotation continues in the stock market. The shift into the defensive sector has been occurring as the market remains near record highs.Utilities Select Sector SPDR (XLU) is building the right side of a flat base with a 56 buy point and is about 2% below the entry. It tracks the S&P Utilities Select Sector, which is made up of companies that produce, distribute or transmit electricity or natural gas. XLU's biggest holdings as of Oct. 25 were NextEra Energy (NEE), at about 10%; Duke Energy (DUK) and Southern Co. (SO), at 8% each; and Dominion Energy (D), at 7%.Its performance is trailing the broader market this year with a year-to-date return of 15.3% through Oct. 25, according to Morningstar Direct, vs. the S&P 500's 16.1% gain. XLU saw average annual returns of 10.8%, 12.3% and 6.9% over the past three, five and 10 years, respectively, while the S&P 500's results were 11.5%, 15% and 7.7%. But XLU beat the benchmark index over the past 15 years with an 11.8% vs. 9.5% gain.Utilities are known for their oft-generous dividends, and XLU is no exception. Its annualized yield of 3.2% handily outpaces the S&P 500's average 1.9% payout. The ETF carries a 0.14% expense ratio.IBD'S TAKE: NextEra Energy has delivered a solid performance this year, but how do its fundamentals and technicals rank in its industry group? The top holdings included the same names as XLU: NextEra, Duke, Southern and Dominion.The fund gained 15.2% this year through Oct. 25, with average annual returns of 11.2%, 12.8% and 7.3%, respectively, over the past three, five and 10 years. The top large-cap, small-cap and midcap ETFs of 2016 focus on dividend payers, giving them a value skew that paid off big in a year when investors grew wary of expensive names amid tepid earnings growth.Here is a look at the winning trio:Click Here To See The Best And Worst ETFs Of 2016Oppenheimer Ultra Dividend Revenue (RDIV), the top-performing large-cap ETF of 2016, selects the 60 highest-yielding stocks from the S&P 500 and S&P 400. It then ranks or weights them by top-line revenue rather than the traditional market capitalization.Revenue weighting offers diversified exposure to the market unlike some smart-beta or alternatively weighted strategies, according to Oppenheimer. And it is less likely to be full of trendy, overpriced stocks than a traditional, market-cap-weighted strategy, the firm's analysts say.Additionally, revenue, unlike earnings, is less susceptible to manipulation and, unlike dividends, is less vulnerable to shifts in management decisions, in Oppenheimer's view.The fund rebalances on a quarterly basis.In 2016, RDIV jumped 28.3% vs. a 12.0% gain for large-cap peer SPDR S&P 500 (SPY).Assets under management: $337.2 millionInception date: Sept. 30, 2013Expense ratio: 0.39%Yield: 3.27%Number of holdings: 60Assets in top 10 holdings: 49.72%Top holdings: Phillip Morris (PM), Verizon (VZ), Duke Energy (DUK)ProShares Russell 2000 Dividend Growers (SMDV), the top-performing small-cap ETF of 2016, invests in Russell 2000 companies that have grown dividends for at least 10 consecutive years.That's a tough bar for most small companies, and gives the ETF an extremely concentrated portfolio.Companies that grow dividends have historically outperformed those that do not, according to ProShares. Additionally, the typically strong fundamentals and stable earnings of dividend growers help them to deliver strong returns with lower volatility.The fund employs a 30% cap on any individual sector weighting to reduce risk, and rebalances four times a year. Stocks are equal weighted.In 2016, SMDV vaulted 35.7% vs. a 21.6% gain for iShares Russell 2000 (IWM).AUM: $349.2 millionInception date: Feb. 3, 2015Expense ratio: 0.40%Yield: 1.40%Number of holdings: 60Assets in top 10 holdings: 19.49%Holdings include: GATX Corp (GATX), Cass Information Systems (CASS), York Water Co. (YORW)ProShares S&P MidCap 400 Dividend Aristocrats (REGL), the top-performing midcap ETF of 2016, focuses on companies in the S&P MidCap 400 index that have grown dividends for at least 15 consecutive years.Like its small-cap sibling, this ETF is equal-weighted, caps sector weightings to no more than 30%, and rebalances four times a year.In 2016, REGL advanced 33.7% vs. a 20.5% gain for SDPR S&P MidCap 400 (MDY).AUM: $311.8 millionInception date: Feb. 3, 2015Expense ratio: 0.40%Yield: 1.34%Number of holdings: 44Assets in top 10 holdings: 24.96%Holdings include: Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK), Lincoln Electric (LECO), Brown & Brown (BRO)RELATED:2017 Personal Finance Action Plan & 2016 Stock Market ReviewSmall-Cap Value ETFs Show Again Why They Are Darlings Of The Market

Stocks fell broadly after the Federal Reserve confirmed a widely anticipated decision to boost interest rates by a quarter point, its second over the past year. The major indexes rallied, then sank hard after the announcement, yet action remained volatile.The fed funds rate, now at a target range of 0.5%-0.75%, is still well below the 5.25% level seen exactly six years ago.The Fed noted in a release that the labor market "has continued to strengthen" and economic activity expanded "at a moderate pace since mid-year," but the U.S. central bank also wrote that inflation, while rising, "is still below the Committee's 2 percent longer-run objective."Meanwhile, IBD reported that the Fed may be on pace to increase interest rates an additional three times in 2017."This time last year the Fed turned out to be wildly off mark in what they were predicting," Luke Bartholomew, an investment manager at $405 billion Aberdeen Asset Management, told IBD. "But this year there are reasons for thinking the Fed's guidance is more realistic. The economy is in a more advanced stage of recovery and market pricing reflects this. We can expect rates to slowly climb through next year and beyond."The Nasdaq composite, fresh from Tuesday's 0.9% rally, fell 0.5% in the stock market today. The Nasdaq-100, a big winner on Tuesday as it rallied 1.3%, retreated from a mild gain to lose 0.3%.The S&P 500 slid 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrials 0.6%. The NYSE composite lost 1.2% as gold mining, oil field services, ship transport and utility stocks got hammered following the raise in the cost of money. Duke Energy (DUK) fell 2.3% and Consolidated Edison (ED) dropped 2.8%. The latter is trying to find buying support at the 50-day moving average.Verizon (VZ), which also borrows much debt to finance its investments in new infrastructure, dropped 1.4% to 51.63. It's in the middle of a new base-building phase after a January breakout past a 47.33 buy point led to a gain of as much as 20%.Small-cap stocks got beaten up the most following the Fed news. The Russell 2000 fell nearly 1% to hit session lows. Volume was still lower at 2:30 p.m. ET compared with the same time Tuesday, but expected to rise by day's end following the Fed move.Meanwhile, Nvidia (NVDA) looked poised to triple in price from its breakout while Tesla Motors (TSLA) advanced further after reclaiming its 50-day moving average, closing above the midterm support line for the first time since late August.Nvidia barreled as much as 6% higher to 97.11, posting an all-time high, before finishing the session at 96.45. Tesla shares edged 0.3% higher to 198.69.Apple (AAPL) also showed resilience following a string of gains lately; shares added nearly 0.5% to 115.75, up 4.8% past an old 110.33 buy point, before fading to a breakeven close at 115.19. The megacap tech, with a market value of $614 billion, is forming a new base now that would qualify as a base-on-base pattern, given that the Sept. 14 breakout past 110.33 did not achieve a minimum 20% advance.Nvidia broke out of an 11-week cup with handle at 33.16 in mid-March. The initial volume was below average, but then ran 40% above its 50-day average turnover on March 18 as shares jumped 3% to 33.81. At that point, the stock was still in buying range.Since then, the emerging leader in chip technology for video graphics, self-driving cars and machine learning has shown incredible strength throughout a choppy 2016, pulling back to actually touch its 50-day moving average only twice during the run and falling near the 50-day line a couple of other times.IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia, which is expanding its presence in increasingly hot tech and consumer markets, was one of several chip stocks moving on analyst actions Wednesday.At the breakout, Nvidia's profit increases were actually on the mild side, yet as a big-cap name the growth was acceptable. Earnings per share rose 34%, 14%, 13% and 18% in the four quarters through the fiscal third quarter ended in October 2015. Sales had risen 9%, 4%, 5% and 6% vs. year-ago levels over the same time frame.However, this year has witnessed growth acceleration.The Santa Clara, Calif., firm's earnings jumped 21% in the quarter ended in January, just ahead of that breakout, as revenue climbed 12%, the biggest increase in five quarters.Since then, earnings per share have grown even faster, picking up 39%, 56% and 104% in the quarters ended April, July and October, as revenue sped up 13%, 24% and 54%. These numbers underline Nvidia's 99 Composite Rating and 96 EPS Rating, according to IBD Stock Checkup.In the fiscal third quarter ended in October, net margin leapt nearly 800 basis points, from 19.5% in the year-ago period to 28.4%, a multiyear record.Nvidia pays a cash dividend of 14 cents a share, equal to an annualized yield of 0.6%.Rob Lutts, CIO of Cabot Wealth Management, notes that "Nvidia has unlocked the key to ultra-fast computing" and that the company's largest target markets are transportation, internet, deep learning and video games. Lutts also told IBD that he compares investing in Nvidia shares to "buying shares of Intel in 1982."Apple, meanwhile, qualifies as a dividend play with a 2% yield. However, with Apple Watch sales said to be strong according to CEO Tim Cook, outstanding double-digit growth in its services revenue, and the small possibility that Apple will post an EPS increase in the December quarter, it's hard not to view the company as a future large-cap growth play as well.Wall Street sees fiscal 2017 profit rising 8% to $9.01 a share and FY 2018 profit up 12% to $10.05 a share.Apple is creeping closer to a potential 118.79 buy point of a base-on-base pattern.Tesla has long been suffering in a slump, but the correction may eventually set up a new base that puts the stock in a position to break out to 52-week highs. The decline after a failed breakout in July 2015 shows classic action in which investors are getting both shaken out and worn out of the stock. But it could be months before a proper buy area emerges.The electric car and SUV leader still shows sign of heavy institutional selling pressure due to its weak 22 RS Rating (out of a maximum 99) and 0.8 up/down volume ratio, also seen in IBD Stock Checkup. But the Accumulation/Distribution Rating of C- is just a notch below the neutral C reading.A potential buy point for now may be at 236.73, 10 cents above the Aug. 1 high within a multimonth consolidation.RELATED:The Bottoming Base Pattern, Part I: Why It Helps Investors Make MoneyThe Bottoming Base Pattern, Part II: How Apple Formed One In 2009The Case for A Trump Era New Secular Bull MarketWhich Techs Beside Apple May Be Preparing To Break Out?

Looking at IBD's 197 industry groups, the gas distribution, diversified, and electric power groups all gained 0.7% to 0.8% Monday. Why? With the market expecting the Federal Reserve on Wednesday to raise the fed funds rate on overnight loans to big banks,…

Loose wiring or faulty circuit can call for emergency repairs to your home electrical system. Right now, the chart action of utility funds is signaling the need for some immediate attention too."Defensive sectors like utilities and telecom did pretty well earlier this year, but of late, investors have been warming up to higher growth sectors, technology in particular," said Neena Mishra, director of ETF research for Zacks Investment Research. She thinks stretched valuations in defensive sectors may be driving investors toward others that don't look too pricey too.Utility Select Sector SPDR (XLU) lost hundreds of millions in net outflow in each month of the third quarter, though it has grown assets this year to $7.31 billion.This bellwether exchange traded fund offers exposure to 28 electric and gas utilities as well as diversified power companies in the S&P 500. Its top holdings include NextEra Energy (NEE), Duke Energy (DUK) and Southern Co. (SO). It yields 3.27%.XLU vaulted 15.5% in the first quarter amid investors' quest for safety and income. By comparison, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), a proxy for the broad U.S. market, trudged up 1.4% in the same period.Now this utility ETF sits 10% below the early July high of 53.02 after losing support at key levels of short-term and long-term support over the past six trading sessions. Treasury yields jumped Tuesday on growing expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike later this year. That makes dividend-paying utilities relatively less attractive.Ari Wald, a senior technical analyst at Oppenheimer & Co., believes utilities could continue to be at risk. If the S&P continues its long-term advance, more cyclical sectors are likely to be rewarded.His firm downgraded the utility sector to underweight in August.IBD'S TAKE: Gold and rate-sensitive equity sectors have come under pressure as the outlook for the next Federal Reserve rate hike remains murky.Despite XLU's recent woes, or perhaps because of it, Wald thinks it has become tactically attractive. He finds the ETF is increasingly oversold and due for a bounce."A rally back above the ETF's 200-day moving average at $48.50 would be an encouraging start," Wald told IBD on Monday. On the stock market today, XLU fell a further 2.1% to 47.29 -- its lowest level since April.Sector rotations are the hallmark of a healthy bull market, Wald added, because "no sector becomes so extended to the upside or the downside to derail the market's broader advance."Mishra sees another reason that utilities could be in favor again. She expects more volatility in the coming weeks as the presidential election approaches and the earnings season picks up pace. With the markets pricing in a Clinton victory, a tighter race and potential Trump win could trigger a broad market sell-off."In such a scenario, I wouldn't be surprised to see some money moving back into defensive sectors until there is better visibility for the market," Mishra said.But she's not expecting a utilities rally like the one earlier this year, and she's bearish on the sector in the longer term.The Fed's latest signals have upped the odds of a hike in interest rates in December, she pointed out. Yield-bearing equity sectors, such as utilities and REITs, sell off when rates are rising.RELATED:Gold ETF Tumbles To Its Lowest Level Since Brexit Vote
